subtasks: Selecting seeds for indoor starting, such as tomatoes, peppers, eggplants, broccoli, cauliflower, lettuce, spinach, and kale.
Preparing seed trays with high-quality seed starting mix and ensuring even moisture without waterlogging.
Planting seeds at the correct depth, typically a quarter inch or half inch depending on the crop.
Maintaining appropriate temperature ranges for germination (warmth for warm-season, cooler for cool-season crops) using grow lights, heat mats, or appropriate environments.
Providing adequate light through bright windows or grow lights, ensuring at least six hours for sun-loving crops like tomatoes and peppers.
Regularly checking and maintaining consistent moisture levels, avoiding overwatering which can lead to root rot.
Gradually acclimating seedlings to outdoor conditions over several weeks before transplanting, including hardening off techniques like increasing outdoor time daily.
Ensuring cool-season crops are grown at optimal temperatures (broccoli 60-65°F, cauliflower 60-70°F), while warm-season crops need warmth (tomatoes, peppers, eggplants at 70-80°F).
Monitoring seedling health, checking for pests and diseases, and addressing issues promptly.
Applying gentle handling, such as brushing seedlings to mimic wind, to promote strong stem development for better outdoor transplanting.
